sections.heading: 8 Meaning of “good”
sections.text: When you say that something is good, you are merely expressing that you like it, rather than referring to something objective about it. When you say "something is good," you are tacitly referring to the object (usually the speaker) to which it is good. Again, it is not because it is good that I want it, but vice versa. There is no "good," but people's desire to have it. This is another example of inappropriate linguistic forms being expressed in statements whose superficial grammatical form erroneously hypothesizes non-existent objects of various kinds. Delicious food is delicious just because we have a strong desire to eat it, and not because of "deliciousness." Water is 80 ° C and refers to a goal of water, while the statement that water is hot refers to one's own desire. The same argument applies to "beauty."

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: In order to determine what an emotion is, we need to find a scientifically defined concept of emotion that corresponds to our everyday concept of emotion. So what we should do is make the everyday concept clear - express it explicitly. Conceptualization is difficult when we try to express knowledge about the everyday, "healthy" world. Consequently, existing theories stop at the level of "semantic primitives," which are considered indefinable. In this paper, we have shown how to divide these "atoms" into smaller "particles"; we show how semantic primitives can be further defined in a formal way.

metadata.abstractText: This paper is motivated by a series of (related) questions as to whether a computer can have pleasure and pain, what pleasure (and intensity of pleasure) is, and, ultimately, what concepts of emotion are. To determine what an emotion is, is a matter of conceptualization; namely, understanding and explicitly encoding the concept of emotion as people use it in everyday life. This is a notoriously difficult problem (Frijda, 1986; Fehr & Russell, 1984). This paper firstly shows why this is a difficult problem by aligning it with the conceptualization of a few other so called semantic primitives such as “EXIST”, “FORCE”, “BIG” (plus “LIMIT”). The definitions of these thought-to-be-indefinable concepts, given in this paper, show what formal definitions of concepts look like and how concepts are constructed. As a by-product, owing to the explicit account of the meaning of “exist”, the famous dispute between Einstein and Bohr is naturally resolved from linguistic point of view. Secondly, defending Frijda’s view that emotion is action tendency (or Ryle’s behavioral disposition (propensity)), we give a list of emotions defined in terms of action tendency. In particular, the definitions of pleasure and the feeling of beauty are presented. Further, we give a formal definition of “action tendency”, from which the concept of “intensity” of emotions (including pleasure) is naturally derived in a formal fashion. The meanings of “wish”, “wait”, “good”, “hot” are analyzed.
